Description: Limestone figure of Osiris seated on a high backed throne. Osiris wears the atef-crown, false-beard, and holds a was sceptre at his chest that extends down to his feet. His eyes are rounded with a thick ridge indicating the upper eyelid, and his nose is slim with the right side now partly damaged. His lips are thick and pursed together. His head is tilted upwards. His body is mummified. At his feet are the remains of a paper label, now illegible. Across the top of the base is a single line of hieroglyphic text with some of the god's epithets. The throne may once have been round-topped, however the tip of this is now lost. There are numerous gouges to the stone at the edges of the throne and corners of the base.
Curator's comments: Such a statue may once have been painted in bright colours or decorated with ornate gilded detail, however no trace of these remain.
